text:
"HeaderName index.head" fails (i.e. it does not include the file) because there
is no MIME type definition for .head. Exactly the same configuration works with
"HeaderName head.html". (In both cases the file is there and readable.)

The same holds for ReadmeName.

I think at least the server error.log should contain a note if the directive is
ignored.
creator: cb@df7cb.de

text:
I think index.head should be included as text/plain in your case (assuming the
default mime type is set to text/plain as it is by default, and content
negotiation is enabled)

Another problem I had was that the online documentation says that if set to
"HeaderName README" then if README.html is not found it will fall back to README
Actually, it falls back to README.txt (As correctly documented in a comment in
httpd.conf)
creator: stu@xanboo.com
tangentangle@hotmail.com
text:
(In reply to comment #1)
 if README.html is not found it will fall back to README
> Actually, it falls back to README.txt 

on my installation of 1.3 putting a file README into a directory is accepted
when there is no README.html. In fact, in a directory where there is a
README.gz, and no mime-type for .gz is defined for the server, it displays the
content of the gzipped file as garbage graphic characters. Which would be a bug
if it does the same in version 2.0+
